corpus.text: Phonemes are the smallest units of sound that distinguish meaning between words in a language. Not physical sounds but mental categories. Example: /p/ and /b/ are different phonemes because 'pat' and 'bat' have different meanings. Languages vary in phoneme inventory (English ~44, Hawaiian ~13).

corpus.text: A phoneme is the smallest contrastive unit in the sound system of a language, capable of distinguishing word meaning. Key concepts: (1) Phonemes vs phones - phonemes are abstract mental representations, phones are physical sound realizations, (2) Allophones - variant pronunciations of same phoneme that don't change meaning (aspirated [pʰ] in 'pin' vs unaspirated [p] in 'spin'), (3) Minimal pairs - words differing by single phoneme prove phonemic status ('bit' /bɪt/ vs 'pit' /pɪt/), (4) Language-specific - phoneme inventories vary (English ~44, !Xóõ ~160), what's phonemic in one language may be allophonic in another. Notation: phonemes in slashes /p/, phones in brackets [p]. Distribution: complementary (allophones) vs contrastive (phonemes). Phonological rules describe allophonic variation. Acquisition: infants born able to distinguish all phonemes, specialization occurs by 12 months. Disorders: phonological processing deficits affect reading (dyslexia). Historical change: phonemes merge, split, or shift over time.
